channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Issues Death Terms For 2 in Sect
item.description: The defendants, members of the Church of Almighty God, were sentenced Saturday for the beating death of a woman who rebuffed their attempts to recruit her, state-run news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.N. Patrol Is Attacked in Central Africa
item.description: An armed group fired at a United Nations police patrol monitoring a protest near the airport in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Malala Yousafzai, Youngest Nobel Peace Prize Winner, Adds to Her Achievements and Expectations
item.description: The Nobel Peace Prize awarded to Ms. Yousafzai, 17, underscores the disproportionate expectations surrounding a rights activist who has yet to graduate from high school.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JODI KANTOR
item.media:description: Malala Yousafzai at the United Nations last year. Ms. Yousafzai, 17, is the youngest recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: Kailash Satyarthi’s Nobel Peace Prize Caps Decades of Fighting Child Slavery in India
item.description: Mr. Satyarthi, a co-winner the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize, has labored over India’s numbingly huge problem of child slavery, and his organization is credited with freeing some 70,000 of them.
item.category: Bachpan Bachao Andolan (Save the Childhood Movement)
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Kailash Satyarthi in his office in New Delhi on Friday, after the news broke that he was a co-winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Evolves as It Forms the Vanguard in Ebola Fight
item.description: How the group could do what no one else accomplished in West Africa is explained in part by its self-reliance and a focus on innovation.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK, ADAM NOSSITER and JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Doctors Without Borders worker advising people in Daru, Sierra Leone, on the devastating outbreak of the Ebola virus there.

item.title: Open Source: As Western Bombs Fall on Syria, Western Jihadists Defend Their War on Assad
item.description: The American-led coalition’s bombing of Islamist militants in Syria has focused new attention on the large number of Westerners among their ranks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Officials Admit a ‘Defeat’ by Ebola in Sierra Leone
item.description: The decision to help families treat patients at home signifies a significant shift in the struggle against the rampaging disease.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A body lay at the entrance of a health center in Waterloo, north of Freetown in Sierra Leone. The number of new cases of people infected by Ebola have increased sharply in the past few weeks.

item.title: ISIS Intensifies Siege of Kurdish Enclave in Syria
item.description: The Islamic State is pouring reinforcements into the besieged Syrian city of Kobani, a Kurdish enclave, despite heavy attacks from American-led aircraft.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Turkish army tank units watched Kobani, a city across the border in Syria that is being attacked by the Islamic State from multiple directions.

item.title: Listening Post: Recent White House Memoirs Target Lame Duck Over a Potential Successor
item.description: In the growing crop of tell-alls by former Obama officials, Hillary Rodham Clinton has emerged largely unscathed — proof that it is easier to kick a sitting second-term president than a potential future one.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Leon E. Panetta with Hillary Rodham Clinton in 2009. The two have had a long, complicated relationship, but his new memoir deals with her more gently than it does with President Obama.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Absence at Ritual Fires North Korea Rumors
item.description: The lack of a public appearance by the North Korean leader on a major holiday is likely to fuel speculation about his whereabouts and his grip on power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: South Korean activists released balloons carrying anti-North Korea leaflets at a park near the border in Paju, north of Seoul.

item.title: A Tense Quiet Along the Kashmir Line
item.description: After more than a week of gunfire across the border, India’s leader emphasized military might, while Pakistan said it escorted U.N. officials through the area.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: A Pakistani woman held part of a mortar shell after her house was leveled Wednesday in fighting between Indian and Pakistani forces in Dhamala Hakimwala village in Punjab Province.

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Negotiator Hints at Extended Talks
item.description: Talks over Iran’s nuclear program might be extended if disagreement over remaining issues cannot be resolved by a Nov. 24 deadline, Iran’s top negotiator was quoted as saying.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Abducted Aid Worker Freed
item.description: Bernd Muehlenbeck, a German aid worker who was kidnapped in Pakistan more than two years ago, has been freed in Afghanistan, the German government said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Fighting Displaces Thousands
item.description: About 100,000 people have fled fighting near the capital, Tripoli, in the past three weeks, adding to a growing problem of internal displacement, the United Nations refugee agency said.
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Niger: French Strike a Qaeda Convoy
item.description: French forces destroyed a convoy linked to the terrorist group Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb that was transporting weapons from Libya to Mali, the office of France’s president said.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Equatorial Guinea: A Vice President Is Ordered to Forfeit Assets in the U.S.
item.description: A federal judge in California announced a $30 million settlement that requires Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue to forfeit his assets, including a collection of six life-size statues of Michael Jackson.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Floodwaters Rush Through Genoa
item.description: Flash floods have inundated the port city of Genoa, with two rivers bursting their banks and sending a torrent of water and mud down some streets. One person was confirmed dead in the overnight storm, officials said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.N. Official Expresses Concern Over Level of Sexual Violence
item.description: The United Nations’ special representative on sexual violence in conflict zones said that rapes by armed men in South Sudan were widespread and intolerable.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Some Chinese Leaders Claim U.S. and Britain Are Behind Hong Kong Protests
item.description: Leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong deny assertions that foreign governments are involved in their movement.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A pro-democracy demonstrator in Hong Kong on Friday.

item.title: Fisherman From China Dies in Clash Off S. Korea
item.description: The coast guard had sought to impound a Chinese fishing boat it said was illegally fishing in South Korean waters, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ‘Putin’s Tiger,’ in a Territory Grab All His Own, Swims to China
item.description: A Siberian tiger released into the wild in Russia in the spring crossed a river this week into China, where wildlife officials are tracking his whereabouts.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Kuzya, a Siberian tiger, in May. President Vladimir V. Putin had a personal hand in reintroducing him to the wild.

item.title: Global Response to Ebola Highlights Challenges in Delivering Aid
item.description: As medical teams head to Sierra Leone, a Doctors Without Borders director says a reliance on volunteers, without military aid in setting up facilities, remains a roadblock.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Political Rally in Pakistan Ends in Deadly Stampede
item.description: The government and the party of the opposition politician Imran Khan blamed each other for the disaster, which killed at least seven people.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Lens Blog: Guantánamo’s Surreal Prison Landscape
item.description: Debi Cornwall wanted to see how prisoners and military guards lived at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. She discovered a surreal “paradise” marked by contrast and contradictions.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ

item.title: Lens Blog: Behind Closed Doors, Abuse of Domestic Workers
item.description: Steve McCurry photographed women who left their villages with dreams of a better life. Instead, they found themselves physically abused while in virtual servitude in Asia and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By KIM BARKER
item.media:description: Edwina Antonio-Calimutan has managed a Hong Kong shelter for domestic workers since 1989. She has seen hundreds of abuse cases and says poverty and debt force women to go abroad and endure 16- to 18-hour workdays, inadequate food or even malnutrition and poor accommodation.
